@dc7590 First, I would not use "guys".

And in my experience, the tech scene in RheinMain was always a lot about #business, many usergroup attendees are working in the #financial sector, (#fintech would be too limiting)

If I'm giving feedback and it did not impact me, I'm using "here is what I observe/understand" which puts me in the position of being wrong instead of the other person. 
I always assume they did best and give them the opportunity to reflect and find a better way on their own. https://t.co/93GfbyslPO

and 8+ tabs of Slacks on the left.

If you're an engineer and need an easy to follow algorithm for giving good #feedback, check out non-violent communication:  https://t.co/QWiLvl11Xv

It describes 4 steps which enable you to give feedback while reducing the chance to offend the receiver:
1) Observation: describe the facts (what your are seeing, reading) without evaluating them.
2) Express how this impacted you personally. Do not talk about how others might be impacted, or generalize impact.
3) Describe what you need instead, what would help you. Again, no generalization.
4) Als for a specific, concrete action which would help to achieve what you described in 3. This inverses the feedback from being a request/command to a call for help. This is very powerful!

@dc7590 For me (as a non-native speaker) it is not gender-neutral and especially not inclusive. E.g. see https://t.co/jejYSkgKjN

I would use friends, all, folks.

Intro to #EuroTestConf 2018 with @Singsalad https://t.co/8eNMBuJ7RE
.@gojkoadzic talking about (finally?) painless visual testing. #EuroTestConf https://t.co/Jl1t0D6s83
Gojko is building up to the moment where he tells us that this is no longer true: https://t.co/pR5KZxrip9
"Record+Replay tools (like Selenium) are optimizing the time spent writing tests. This is not where the value is."
Tools like the Galen framework enable you to test UI by describing expectations. Still not optimal, since syntax like this is nothing your users would supply. https://t.co/uYirOfAwN1

https://t.co/ZCKvkCOQ4Y¬†is the tool he developed for visual approval testing. It helps to review and approve changes to web pages, visual layouts and browser components quickly through visual inspection using headless Chrome.
And with headless Chrome you can parallelize the tests using AWS lambda: https://t.co/4JL0reTzs9

"This (visual difference testing and running the browser used to test in parallel) changes the economics of UI testing and makes them something we can now start looking into, because tests are now easy to maintain and extend." https://t.co/AI7dKrxhis

This will be really cool once we have a bot that adds screenshots to a PR when a commit breaks the test, and reviewers can accept / reject changes to the test in the PR. 
No need for a human to maintain the (small changes to the) tests anymore. 

Great talk @gojkoadzic üëè

@dc7590 Try my CC-rule: every mail where I am on CC is moved out of the inbox to a separate folder which I check once a week or fewer times.

Start writing tests as minimal as possible to not let the test implementation architect the implementation.

Don't overthink, but keep notes to self for later. https://t.co/7g9aFCTfsr
A unit test can become stubborn like a donkey if it is too tightly coupled to the implementation. https://t.co/bRVZ6ISBP7

As a lonely TDDer, you sometimes have to suffer for your own art.

Try pairing with team members to show them how to write tests ...

If you are creating non-text output, try finding ways to turn results into plaintext. This enables version-control, search&replace of test acceptance criteria. https://t.co/M1CYSTAJt5
Add tracing IDs to requests which should end up in logs as well so you can find where something failed.
Once more than one team is working on a microservice architecture it gets important to coordinate tests between these teams. https://t.co/klFtHHkS1C
Version control of microservices is very important to enable this.

One interesting idea that came up during the #EuroTestConf lean coffee about:

How to get developers into TDD >

What if we start their TDD experience with integration tests instead of unit tests. 

Provide them with the running skeleton that already has all dependencies like DB running (e.g. in a container) and let them write tests against the public API.
This would remove one of the pains in writing tests: mocking.
